speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your fatigue? Is it constant or does it come and go?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's been constant, doctor. I just feel like I'm running out of energy all the time, even after I rest. It's like I'm dragging myself through the day."

speaker: Doctor
text: Do you have any difficulty swallowing or feeling like food is getting stuck in your throat?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, doctor, I have been having some trouble swallowing lately. It's like my food is taking a bit longer to go down, and sometimes I feel like it's stuck in my throat for a second before it finally passes."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any coughing or shortness of breath?

speaker: Patient
text: "I haven't noticed any coughing, doctor. But sometimes when I'm lying in bed, I do get this weird feeling like I'm choking or suffocating. It's hard to describe, but it's really uncomfortable."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any recent travel or exposure to anyone with a similar illness?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, doctor, I haven't traveled recently and I don't think I've been exposed to anyone with a similar illness. I've just been working at my construction job and hanging out with friends and family."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the abdominal pain you're experiencing? Is it constant or does it come and go, and is it localized to one area or is it more widespread?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's been getting worse over the past few weeks, doctor. The pain is constant, but it's not always the same intensity. Sometimes it's a dull ache, other times it's a sharp stabbing sensation. It's mainly in the upper part of my abdomen, but it can radiate to my back and even my chest sometimes."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your night sweats? How often do you experience them, and do you notice any other symptoms along with them?

speaker: Patient
text: "Ah, the night sweats... it's been happening almost every night, doctor. I wake up drenched in sweat, and it's not just a little bit, it's like I've been swimming in it. And it's not just the sweating, I also feel really hot and flushed, even though my bedroom is cool. Sometimes I'll wake up in the middle of the night feeling like I'm going to pass out, and it takes me a while to calm down and fall back asleep."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any significant weight loss recently?

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, yes, doctor. I've lost a significant amount of weight over the past few months. I've had to get new clothes because my old ones are too big, and I just feel like I'm wasting away. It's been really hard to get used to, and I'm worried about my health."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your supraclavicular lymph node? Is it tender to the touch or is it just enlarged?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, doctor, I've been noticing some swelling in my neck lately. It's been getting worse over the past few days, and it's not just one node, it's like a whole bunch of them are swollen. It doesn't really hurt when I touch it, but it does feel kind of hard and lumpy."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your appetite or taste recently?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, doctor, I have been noticing that food doesn't taste as good as it used to. Everything just seems kind of bland and flavorless. And my appetite has been off too - I'm not as hungry as I usually am, and when I do eat, I don't feel like I'm getting the satisfaction I used to get from a meal."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your bowel movements or difficulty with urination?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, doctor, I have been having some issues with my bowel movements lately. Sometimes I feel like I'm constipated, and other times I have loose stools. It's been really unpredictable, and it's been causing me a lot of discomfort."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the timing of your symptoms? Did they start suddenly or did they develop gradually over time?

speaker: Patient
text: "Well, doctor, I'd say my symptoms started gradually. The fatigue and abdominal pain were the first things I noticed, and they've been getting worse over the past few months. The night sweats and weight loss started a bit later, maybe a few weeks ago. And the neck swelling, like I said, is a more recent development, over the past four days or so."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you have any history of smoking or exposure to secondhand smoke?

speaker: Patient
text: "Ah, yes, doctor. I've been a smoker for about 30 years, one pack a day. I know it's not good for me, but it's been a hard habit to break. And as for secondhand smoke, I'm sure I've been exposed to it at work and in social settings over the years."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your smoking habit? Have you noticed any changes in your cough or shortness of breath recently?

speaker: Patient
text: "Ah, yes, doctor. Like I said, I've been smoking for about 30 years, one pack a day. I know it's not good for me, but it's just something I've always done. And to be honest, I haven't really noticed any changes in my cough or shortness of breath recently. But I do feel like I'm getting winded easier than I used to, especially after physical activity."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent exposure to anyone with a history of tuberculosis?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, doctor, I don't think so. I don't recall anyone in my close circle having a history of tuberculosis. But I do work in construction, so I'm around a lot of people and we're all exposed to different things on the job site."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your job in construction? Do you work with any hazardous materials or substances?

speaker: Patient
text: "Ah, yeah, doctor. I work as a laborer on construction sites. We do a lot of heavy lifting, hauling, and digging, so it's physically demanding. I'm exposed to dust, dirt, and chemicals, but I'm not sure if that's relevant to my symptoms. We do use some heavy machinery and equipment, but I don't think that's a major concern. Just the usual construction stuff, you know?"

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your family medical history? Have you had any close relatives with lung or respiratory problems?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, doctor, my grandfather had some kind of lung disease, I'm not really sure what it was. He was a heavy smoker and died from it when I was a kid. But I don't know if that's relevant to my symptoms. My parents are both healthy, as far as I know. My mom has high blood pressure, but that's about it."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your grandfather's lung disease? Was it diagnosed as tuberculosis?

speaker: Patient
text: "Ah, yeah, doctor, my grandfather's lung disease was diagnosed as tuberculosis. He was in his 50s when he passed away, and I remember my parents telling me that he had been sick for a while before he died. But I don't know if that's related to my symptoms or not. I just know that I've been feeling really unwell lately and I'm worried about my health."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your grandfather's tuberculosis treatment and outcome?

speaker: Patient
text: "Ah, yeah, doctor... I think my grandfather was treated with antibiotics, but I'm not really sure what kind. He was hospitalized for a while, and I remember my parents talking about how serious his condition was. Unfortunately, he didn't recover, and he passed away a few months later. It was a really tough time for our family."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your diet lately? Have you made any significant changes or are you eating the same foods you usually do?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, doctor, I've been trying to eat a bit more healthily lately. I've cut back on the junk food and tried to focus on whole grains and vegetables. But to be honest, I've been having trouble keeping my appetite up, so I'm not eating as much as I used to. And when I do eat, I tend to reach for comfort foods like pasta or pizza, just because they're easy and taste good. But I know that's not the healthiest option."

speaker: Doctor
text: I think we've gotten a good sense of your symptoms and medical history. I'd like to request some test results to help me narrow down the diagnosis. Can I get a chest X-ray and a complete blood count (CBC) please?

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, doctor. I'm willing to do whatever it takes to figure out what's going on with my body. But can you explain to me what these tests are going to show? And how long will it take to get the results?"
